article title: Evaluating the incidence and predictors of anti-NMDAR encephalitis in a contemporary cohort of patients diagnosed with dermoid tumors: A national inpatient sample analysis
classification or diagnosis: ICD-10 codes: D27 (benign dermoid tumor of ovary), G04 (encephalitis and meningitis), along with psychiatric and seizure-related codes
data source: Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project (HCUP) National Inpatient Sample (NIS), 2016
diagnosis criteria details: Diagnosis based on ICD-10 coding for anti-NMDAR encephalitis
population characteristics: Mean age of all dermoid tumor patients: 45.5 ± 18.0 years; Mean age of patients with anti-NMDAR encephalitis: 27.4 ± 4.9 years
population cohort: Patients diagnosed with ovarian dermoid tumors, with or without anti-NMDAR encephalitis

article title: The Antibody Assay in Suspected Autoimmune Encephalitis From Positive Rate to Test Strategies
classification or diagnosis: Antibody-positive AE based on laboratory assay
data source: Laboratory test records from Guizhou KingMed Diagnostics Group
diagnosis criteria details: Based on published AE diagnostic criteria
sites or centers involved: Six medical centers in Guizhou Province

article title: Direct economic burden of patients with autoimmune encephalitis in western China
classification or diagnosis: Antibody-positive AE based on clinical symptoms and laboratory tests
population characteristics: Mixed age and sex distribution, including comorbidities such as tumors
population cohort: Patients with antibody-positive autoimmune encephalitis (anti-NMDAR, anti-GABABR, anti-LGI1, and anti-CASPR2)

article title: Heterogeneous treatment for anti-NMDAR encephalitis in children leads to different outcomes 6–12 months after diagnosis
classification or diagnosis: Diagnosis confirmed by presence of anti-NMDAR antibodies in CSF and/or serum
population cohort: Children diagnosed with anti-NMDAR encephalitis (aged 1 month - 18 years)
prospective or retrospective: Mixed (Retrospective for patients diagnosed before 2016, Prospective after 2016)
sites or centers involved: Single center (Queen Sirikit National Institute of Child Health, Bangkok)
study coverage area: Single hospital study (Queen Sirikit National Institute of Child Health, Bangkok)

article title: Development and Validation of a Risk Score for Predicting ICU Admission in Adults with New-Onset Encephalitis
classification or diagnosis: ICD-9 coded encephalitis with IEC criteria
data source: Hospital discharge records and medical records from two health systems
population characteristics: Median age 49 years, mixed gender, with autoimmune and infectious encephalitis cases
sites or centers involved: Four centers (two in Texas, two in Maryland)
study design: Retrospective cohort study with external validation

article title: Autoimmune encephalitis in a resource-limited public health setting: a case series analysis
population characteristics: Median age 36.2 years, 88% Caucasian, mixed gender
sites or centers involved: Single center (Hospital de Clínicas de Porto Alegre)
study coverage area: Single center (Hospital de Clínicas de Porto Alegre, Brazil)

article title: Neuropsychological outcomes in children and adolescents following anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis
classification or diagnosis: Diagnosis confirmed by presence of NMDAR antibodies in serum and/or CSF
population characteristics: Median age at diagnosis 8.8 years, 65.2% female
population cohort: Pediatric patients diagnosed with anti-NMDAR encephalitis

article title: Clinical characteristics and prognosis analysis of acute symptomatic seizures secondary to autoimmune encephalitis
classification or diagnosis: Graus criteria (2016) and Chinese expert consensus (2022)
diagnosis criteria details: Graus criteria (2016) and Chinese expert consensus (2022)
sites or centers involved: Single center (General Hospital of Ningxia Medical University)
study coverage area: Single hospital study (General Hospital of Ningxia Medical University, Yinchuan)

article title: Higher incidence of acute symptomatic seizures in probable antibody-negative pediatric autoimmune encephalitis than in major antibody-positive autoimmune encephalitis
classification or diagnosis: Autoimmune Encephalitis International Working Group criteria
diagnosis criteria details: Probable antibody-negative AE classification based on clinical features, neuroinflammation markers, and absence of autoantibodies
population cohort: Pediatric patients diagnosed with autoimmune encephalitis (AE)
study coverage area: Single-center study (Osaka City General Hospital, Japan)

article title: Pediatric anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR) encephalitis: Exploring psychosis, related risk factors, and hospital outcomes in a nationwide inpatient sample: A cross-sectional study
classification or diagnosis: ICD-10 diagnostic codes G04.0x to G04.9x
population cohort: Pediatric inpatients diagnosed with anti-NMDAR encephalitis (ages 6–17 years)
sites or centers involved: Nationwide (U.S. hospitals in the NIS database)

article title: Acute pediatric encephalitis: etiology, course, and outcome of a 12-year single-center immunocompetent cohort
diagnosis criteria details: Pediatric AE classification including definite, probable, and possible AE categories
population cohort: Pediatric patients diagnosed with autoimmune encephalitis (AE)

article title: Phenotyping the late- and younger-onset neuronal surface antibody-mediated autoimmune encephalitis: a multicenter study
classification or diagnosis: 2016 Lancet Neurology criteria for autoimmune encephalitis
diagnosis criteria details: NSAE diagnosis based on antibody presence and clinical criteria
disease analysis: Autoimmune encephalitis (AE) subtypes and age-related differences
population cohort: Patients with neuronal surface antibody-mediated autoimmune encephalitis (NSAE)
study coverage area: Multi-center study (three hospitals in Zhejiang province, China)

data source: Hospital billing and electronic medical records
diagnosis criteria details: Antibody-positive AE was confirmed through CSF or serum antibody testing
disease analysis: Autoimmune encephalitis (AE) and its financial burden
population cohort: Adult inpatients diagnosed with autoimmune encephalitis (AE)
sites or centers involved: Two centers (Johns Hopkins Hospital and Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center)
study coverage area: Single institution study (Johns Hopkins Hospital and Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center, Baltimore, MD)

article title: Long-term effects of anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor encephalitis on quality of life
classification or diagnosis: Diagnosis confirmed via cell-based assays (NR1/NR2–transfected HEK293 cells)
disease analysis: Long-term outcomes and quality of life in anti-NMDAR encephalitis (NMDARE)
